summary: pigs of any age could be infected by enteropathogenic viruses such as porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV), transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) and porcine rotavirus (PoRV) the positive rate of PEDV is relatively higher in the whole world and causes considerable economic losses to pig-production in recent years. RT-LAMP and real-time RT-PCR gain more sensitivity than antigen-based methods. real-time RT-PCR requires special instruments and dye-labeled probes, making them unsuitable in clinical practice. nanoparticles have lots of nanometer characteristics, such as multivalency, superparamagnetism, modified functional chemical groups. a functionalized nanoparticles-based PCR method was developed to identify PEDV infection in preclinical stool samples. magnetic microparticles coated with PEDV specific probes and gold nanoparticles coated with PEDV specific oligos were used to enrich viral genomic RNA and amplify weak viral signals from fecal samples. the established UNDP-PCR assay for PEDV is fit for diagnosis in early stage of viral infection. PRRSV Shaanxi strain (GenBank No. HQ401282), TGEV strain (GenBank No. HQ462571), PCV2 strain (GenBank No. EU366323) and PPV YL strain (GenBank No. JN860197) used in this study were isolated and purified previously by our research team. fresh fecal samples were collected from individual pigs on farms. they were placed in sterile specimen cups, kept on ice, and returned to the laboratory time, money and labor, showing a wide detection range and the potential for clinical application.
